question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the least positive integer greater than 1 that leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by each of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9?
inference: Final Answer: $\boxed{2520}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
If $n$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by all of these numbers then $n-1$ is a multiple of all of these.  We compute the LCM of these numbers as  \begin{align*}
\text{lcm}(2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9)&=\text{lcm}(5,6,7,8,9)\\
&=\text{lcm}(5,7,8,9)\\
&=5\cdot7\cdot8\cdot9\\
&=2520.
\end{align*} The smallest $n>1$ that satisfies $2520\mid n-1$ is $n=\boxed{2521}$.

ground_truth:
If $n$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by all of these numbers then $n-1$ is a multiple of all of these.  We compute the LCM of these numbers as  \begin{align*}
\text{lcm}(2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9)&=\text{lcm}(5,6,7,8,9)\\
&=\text{lcm}(5,7,8,9)\\
&=5\cdot7\cdot8\cdot9\\
&=2520.
\end{align*} The smallest $n>1$ that satisfies $2520\mid n-1$ is $n=\boxed{2521}$.
